I rarely leave reviews for games (or anythings at all, honestly), only when something truly captivates me or really disappoints. Town to City is the first case.
This is one of the simplest, coziest, and surprisingly well-crafted city builders I've encountered. You don't need to be an economics genius to keep your city profitable. Citizens won't hate you for every wrong decision and won't flee in droves at your first mistake. You don't need to be an architect or designer for your city to look genuinely beautiful.
That's the main charm of this game. You don't need to try too hard to simply enjoy the process. You build, watch your city grow, and have fun. No stress, no endless micromanagement, no feeling that you're doing something wrong.
Town to City is a game that lets you relax and create at your own pace. If you're tired of complex simulators where every action can lead to collapse, or you just want to spend an evening on something pleasant and meditative - this is your choice.
Wholeheartedly recommended.

Town to City is a cozy voxel-based city builder that offers relaxed, creative gameplay. I've had plenty of fun decorating my towns and managing resident needs such as food, leisure, clothing, and services. Supply chains matter here, as shops must be stocked via runners connected to warehouses through well-planned roads. Maintaining resident happiness above 60% ensures new workers arrive by train. Anything less and you might find yourself in some serious trouble! 

As you progress, you unlock more decor and entire new industries through research, which allow you to meet the demands of higher-class citizens. The game also includes story-driven requests from residents, adding charm and personality to your town.

You begin in Belvau and eventually unlock new maps like Fontebrac, each with unique challenges such as farm production. Since the game is still in early access, some areas and features, like pets and farm animals, are not yet available but are listed on the developers‚Äô roadmap.

A major strength of the game I'd say is its combination of cozy aesthetics with meaningful progression. Players can follow objectives at their own pace or switch to sandbox mode for freeform building. Compared to complex city builders, Town to City keeps management simple: there‚Äôs no deep economic micromanagement or the risk of going into debt.

For me at least, the free-range road-building tool is definitely a standout feature, offering flexible, organic layout options and adjustable road widths. However, buildings sometimes require manual adjustments when placed, even with the ‚Äúsnap to road‚Äù tool.

Overall, I'd say that the game is a charming, low-pressure city builder with satisfying progression and thoughtful design. Though it's still growing as an early access title, I'd highly recommend the game to any cozy game or (casual) city-builder fan!

This is THE aesthetic city builder for me! The game balances perfectly between being relatively easy but also keeping things interesting. It has just enough challenge in how you upgrade the cities, satisfy the needs of the citizens and the specific quest goals to keep things interesting. Meanwhile things never really get so dire that if you want to just take a while to decorate with the game unpaused the whole world isn't going to go up in flames- everything will be fine. And that's why this qualifies inherently as a chill game, in the best way possible. 
The art style is absolutely gorgeous and importantly for the game it really works at both a micro and macro level. It's fun to see your bustling town either from a far distance or really up close as you add individual details to the buildings. Also there's something extremely fun and innovative about how they've handled the decoration assets. The fact that assets change whether you're adding them to a building or on ground or on the water not only keeps the decoration menu smaller, since they don't have to add every single iteration of an asset, but it also adds this wonderful sense of discovery. You unlocked something new? Time to see what it's going to look like in the possible different states! I kept discovering new things I could do with the decorations and it really added a lot of joy to the game. 
Overall this game is really a 10/10, I haven't tried the sandbox stage yet but I'm mostly just looking forward to new expansions and updates and seeing where this game will go. I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys building and decoration in games, city planning, or just a chill experience in general!

Commenting after 47 hours of game time.  

The game is in Early access, and has only been out for a couple of months.  You will recognise the gameplay loop from similar games in the past (and currently), but this one does have some differences - especially with its decorations and ways of keeping your citizens happy.

As for the amount of content, it has a few sandbox maps and a campaign that allows you to link up 2 maps to 'feed' each other with resources.  There is a third map planned, and once you hit 40 hours or so, you will want that map to materialise fairly soon.

One thing I would really like is the ability to link up multiple maps in sandbox mode, but you can't.  Therefore you end up hitting the 1000 citizen cap really fast.  It does let you go further but it warns you that the game isn't optimised for it.  So far, I've made a city with about 1300 citizens, and I still have room  for more.  If you linked up the maps, you could have 1000 in each of those maps, link up resources, and then you wouldn't have an issue with optimisation.

Anyway, this isn't a review as such, but just some comments about the game as it is should you be researching it and considering buying it.  Well, in a world where there are now dozens of choices in this genre - and I have most of them, Town to City does stand out in it's own way, it just needs a bit more content and maybe punch up a bit when it comes to difficulty.

For an early access game, in its current state, I'd give it 8/10.  I'm sure there is a lot more to come, but I might give it a break for a month or so when the pets and animals update is well bedded in.
It's a game that lets you strive towards concrete in-game goals but also lets you just slow down. A practice in mindfulness for my depressed self honestly.

I think this is my first review, but I truly felt like this game deserves it! I have tried a handful of city builders in the past that market themselves as cozy and low-stress. Yet, as a stressed person, I always end up returning them as they fall short of my expectations or become too complicated. 
This brings me to Town to City, my boyfriend convinced me to get it on sale, and I am so happy I took the chance. I have been utterly obsessed with this game. I even took to playing it in the car whenever I have a long enough ride. The mechanics are very easy to learn and this game does not punish you for having a slow pace, if anything, they encourage it. I enjoy that this game has a decorating aspect that is VERY tapped into. The NPCs have their own wants and needs, some even asking you for specific areas, like parks or romantic areas. As someone who struggles with creativity, I have been decorating my town to my hearts content. One of the mechanics I enjoy the most is the happiness meter, I love making my citizens happy and trying to figure out the root of the problem. I have even taken to looking at real towns to beautify my own. 
I always struggle with using too much money or feeling like i need to tear down places to replace them when playing other games, but I have not ran into this issue. Town to City offers multiple buildings under the same category with varying prices and range, if you're running low on money (which rarely happens) its easy to work around and you can very quickly make your money back. People really seem to love this game, and honestly I'm torn because at its core, I also love this game.  I think it has a beautiful artistic style, I think its approach to the genre is interesting and fun.  But I also really found it pretty boring after a short while, and it became obvious that the "progression" was just going to be a lot of rinse and repeat without much in the way of advancement or real achievement.  People want things, you give them those things, over and over and over.  Is this a core mechanic of this genre?  Sure.  But the way this game goes about it is just... dull.

I know it's meant to be relaxing, and a lot of the reviews emphasize how chill it is, but honestly I found it rather directionless.  This family needs a house with trees?  Plop down some trees.  Hooray, now they're happy.  This family wants water nearby?  Plop a house next to some water.  Hooray, they're happy now.  And while this is all simple and well and good for it, it just gets... boring.  And tedious.  And repetitive.  And not in the fun way a lot of games in this bracket can make it.  Again, I know this is meant to be a "relaxing" approach to a "city building" game, and it is definitely that.  And if you're someone who just wants to have a pretty game to look at on the side with no real investment in the development of your town beyond "I planted some flowers and now they're happier", then by all means, this is the game for you.

Honestly, judging by the reviews, this is obviously the game for a vast majority of the people playing this.  Which is honestly a bit confusing and maybe a little concerning, to consider the bar is apparently so low for thousands of people.  But, I grasp that I'm in the minority here, and very probably not the intended audience for this game.  And again, I don't think this is a "bad" game, it's just nothing impressive, especially not for $25 in Early Access.  There are plenty of other games in this genre that are in the same state of completion, if not further (or even released) for the same price or a few dollars more.  They'll give you 10x the content, engagement, and sense of accomplishment that this game will.  But if you don't want those things, and you instead just want to plop a few things down and feel like you've "built a town" then by all means, buy this and never look back.

Maybe I'll come back to this someday when there's more content.  I picked it up as soon as it came out because I loved the concept and the look of it, and I'm all for supporting smaller devs, but it just felt shallow, hollow, lackluster.  Pretty to look at, ugly to play.  And I returned it almost instantly, because the mundane nature of the whole thing was quickly apparent, and I didn't want to miss that 2 hour window.

I wanted to like this game, I genuinly enjoyed the demo and thought the game would be incredible once it releases, but what I expected from a full release didn't materialise, not even close.

What I want to make clear here is that this is not a game for me, not that it is a bad game. 

I expected this game to be a city builder, but it is closer to a diorama builder. The maps are tiny, cramped, even the full flat map feels too small. I absolutely love beautybuilding in city builders, but for some reason developers of all city builders besides Cities Skylines (and technically them too) have this urge to limit the size of their map. Why? What compells all developers to make maps so small? It's not performance I tell you, because all they'd need to do is limit the size and allow you to build over the limit by ticking some box in options, Rimworld does this perfectly for instance. They even warn you there about increasing size having big impact on performance, but they give you a choice. The implications are massive. Everything you can build will feel like a miniature city. I don't want miniature, I want full scale. I want to build whole countryside, not a fraction of it. Give me kilometers of farmlands, woodlands, I love scale.

It's not about the urban target of the game's theme that has to limit the size. In fact the game isn't much of a town to city as it is village to town, so it should feel much larger than it is. While detailing is awesome and I absolutely love it, the building selection further proves that the game is meant to look good as a miniature. Signature buildings look too distinct to blend well, at least some of them and their inclusion also makes little sense since the map is so small and you really aren't going to find most towns of such size to have as huge buildings. Just look at the fountain and this little castle/masnion/chateau thing among some others. Or how large the train station gets by the end. There are exceptions of course, but most towns of such size should feel less grandeur. To me city building is about trying to build something both unique and realistic. For that you need huge building variety, detailing, and scale. This game to me offers the best detailing experience I have ever seen, but not the other two things. In fact scale is probably among the worst and building variety is fair for an indie title at this price, fair doesn't mean good, it means, acceptable.

Another thing that bothers me to no end and that wasn't fixed since demo, the clothing store, and likely many other buildings, still enforce a partial perimeter of grass around them, meaning even if you want to have it near a plaza, you will have to suffer a patch of grass that looks totally out of place. You can't build over it either. For some reason only Cities Skylines allows anarchy. I don't care about overlap, let me overlap, let me clip. But no, I will have to be forbidden from doing this rather than given a choice. Just highlight it in yellow to indicate clipping. So if this bug wasn't fixed for a couple of months, it's not a good sign, what else will I find broken while playing naturally? Such things are my pet peeve, if you give me a game about detailing and make it impossible and glaring, I will suffer.

To me this is a real shame, because this game put tons of love and care into detailing, the models look great, the atmosphere is amazing, you can really feel the heart was poured into this, but what good is that when it's so small. I'd rather play Anno or Cities Skylines. Not because of the simulation or theme or other mechanics, purely from the perspective of building something nice. Scale matters in city builders, correct distance between certain areas does matter. Even the rular areas need correct size, bigger is better always.

The game is going to be updated over time, but I doubt my concerns are going to get any attention from the looks of the roadmap, and that's fine, the game is simply meant for a different audience than me. And that's why I in particular can't recommend this in good faith despite game likely ending with 95%+ positive reviews. That's the core audience, not me. It is an early access title, but it's not going to go in a direction I need, and that's fine again, just not for me in particular.

What I can tell you is that if you are okay with this scale, if you like the particular style they went for, go for it, it's an amazing game for you. But if like me, you feel like all city builders lack something important, this game lacks it more than others, despite appearing at first like it holds some hidden potential.

I think it's important to be honest and up front with Town to City.

While the pixel art aesthetic and the lego-style snap on decorations can feel refreshing, it masks what is essentially a very, very small and very simplified version of Anno 1800.  From your commerce buildings needing to be within a certain proximity of a warehouse to your citizens needing to be within a certain proximity of your commerce, anyone looking to advance their village in size will eventually abandon their plans for one or two optimal layouts.  This approach bars any future inclusion of strategic infrastructure (utilities, transportation, etc), so fans of builders like Surviving Mars or City Skylines will come away empty handed.

Add to this the fact that almost half of the families moving into your little hamlet will have their own esoteric needs on top of the ones shared by all citizens.  Some will need to live by the water, while others need to live near trees.  The maps are so small however that your only recourse is to add more stories to your homes to fit more families.  This in turn means that you'll need more commerce buildings in order to keep your new citizens happy.  You won't have enough workers though, so you'll need more families to work those jobs.  More workers means more houses which means more space between homes and commerce which means you'll need more commerce buildings, and so on and so on.  The end result is a game of whack-a-mole to get rid of the overly large, frowny face icons littering your view.

That's not to say that the game is difficult, quite the opposite.  By the time your town reaches the third level you'll have more money than you'll ever need with nothing to counteract it.  This results in an extremely restrictive experience with very little challenge.

I think the vast majority of players who give this a shot will consider it a nice aside and never play it again.

Lets start by saying Game looks gorgeous but far too fiddly for me. AI isnt great and the shop system needs a bit of work.

People really seem to love this game, and honestly I'm torn because at its core, I also love this game.  I think it has a beautiful artistic style, I think its approach to the genre is interesting and fun.  But I also really found it pretty boring after a short while, and it became obvious that the "progression" was just going to be a lot of rinse and repeat without much in the way of advancement or real achievement.  People want things, you give them those things, over and over and over.  Is this a core mechanic of this genre?  Sure.  But the way this game goes about it is just... dull.

I know it's meant to be relaxing, and a lot of the reviews emphasize how chill it is, but honestly I found it rather directionless.  This family needs a house with trees?  Plop down some trees.  Hooray, now they're happy.  This family wants water nearby?  Plop a house next to some water.  Hooray, they're happy now.  And while this is all simple and well and good for it, it just gets... boring.  And tedious.  And repetitive.  And not in the fun way a lot of games in this bracket can make it.  Again, I know this is meant to be a "relaxing" approach to a "city building" game, and it is definitely that.  And if you're someone who just wants to have a pretty game to look at on the side with no real investment in the development of your town beyond "I planted some flowers and now they're happier", then by all means, this is the game for you.

Honestly, judging by the reviews, this is obviously the game for a vast majority of the people playing this.  Which is honestly a bit confusing and maybe a little concerning, to consider the bar is apparently so low for thousands of people.  But, I grasp that I'm in the minority here, and very probably not the intended audience for this game.  And again, I don't think this is a "bad" game, it's just nothing impressive, especially not for $25 in Early Access.  There are plenty of other games in this genre that are in the same state of completion, if not further (or even released) for the same price or a few dollars more.  They'll give you 10x the content, engagement, and sense of accomplishment that this game will.  But if you don't want those things, and you instead just want to plop a few things down and feel like you've "built a town" then by all means, buy this and never look back.

Maybe I'll come back to this someday when there's more content.  I picked it up as soon as it came out because I loved the concept and the look of it, and I'm all for supporting smaller devs, but it just felt shallow, hollow, lackluster.  Pretty to look at, ugly to play.  And I returned it almost instantly, because the mundane nature of the whole thing was quickly apparent, and I didn't want to miss that 2 hour window.
